comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: I know that this must have been very hard work, but there is something about this photo and how relaxed they all look, as well as the magnificent scenery, that makes me think it would also have been a great day for all involved...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30484128@N03
comment._content:
Better than working deep underground in a coal mine.
And fascinating things can turn up in the turf from ancient times.

comment.author: 52955671@N07
comment._content: Its Peat in Scotland, looks very similar.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/30484128@N03] Like the 8th century Faddan More Psalter, Jim, found in a bog in Offaly just 5 years ago: www.museum.ie/en/list/projects.aspx?article=27229a4b-9f2f...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/52955671@N07] We say peat too, Euan, and I tagged Peat, but in this context, think we'd more naturally refer to Turf in Ireland - have never heard anyone say "Footing the Peat" - unless of course, someone out there knows different...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30484128@N03
comment._content:
We normally say "peat" in America, too. "Turf" in America usually refers to grass, as on a football field.

Old Irish folk songs, though, often had the phrase "cutting the turf."

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: And this just in, another bog body has been found in Portlaoise (Irish Midlands): www.rte.ie/news/2011/0811/portlaoise.html Whatever we call it - Peat or Turf - it is truly amazing stuff...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30484128@N03
comment._content: It is a great natural time capsule.

comment.author: 82836674@N00
comment._content: An epic vista, it's like the bawg version of the iconic "workmen on a girder"     :)

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pollybean] Hello Paula - haven't heard from you in ages! Or "I thought you were dead" as my mother usually greets long absent friends/family... :)

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: This is bandit country: looking WNW down over Ravensdale and across the border towards Jonesborough in South Armagh. The turfcutting sites on Black Mountain can be seen in the Google maps aerial view. No streetview up there, though!
